text: Sweet grain malts, caramel, molasses, sweet, dark fruits, prune. Hazy, very dark brown, small, light beige head. Light sweet. More sweet grain and cereal malts, bread, dough, light molasses, dark fruits, flat carbonation, full bodied. Nice, rich and complex. Cask at the brewery, York.

Cask Pint at Wibbas Down (JDW), Wimbledon, London in May 2010 - Very Dark Brown; Red against the light. Very Malty; dark chocolate, coffee, roasty malts. Fruity; berries and dried fruits. Hoppy; slightly earthy hops. Porterish. Bitter roast chocolate malty. Dry bitter chocolate finish. Nice beer! (2010-05)
Taste of caramel with some malts on top. Very satisfying dark ale. A York brewery classic.
Cask at York brewery. Red color and very thick, lacing foam malt aroma. Great, silky smooth palate. Malt flavor. Lots of flavor for a mild. Dry grain finish.
On tap at the Brewery Tap room. Dark ruby beer with a light pale bridge head.  Malty taste and aroma, light sweet to mid bitter taste.  medium body.

Cask at the source. Dark clear maroon brown color, fine tan head with good retention and solid lacing. Nice aroma of cocoa powder and coffee grounds. Taste is sweet roast, lightly bitter dry finish. Tasty.

Cask. Last Drop Inn, York. Dark, ruby red. Thin, creamy, dense, clingy, beige head. Looks great. Nose has vine fruits. Cake mixture. Nutty milk chocolate. Soft caramel. Taste has a vine fruit dryness. Some stickiness on the lips. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel. Finishes soft sweet, with more of the vine fruits. Excellent.
On cask at Yorkshire Terrier York a deep ruby almost brown beer roast malt fruity aroma flavour is ripe berries dark chocolate roast coffee hint of treacle smooth roasted malt finish

Tap. The Ghost is dark amber to brownish in color with a nice and smooth creamy head, that is tan and long lasting. In the nose the aroma is dominated by dark malts with notes coffee and dark chocolate as well as some berries in the back. The flavor stays this with roasty and coffee notes. The taste is not sweet but dry and get bitter in the end. The finish therefore is pleasantly bitter while the medium body and carbonation contain all these aspects in a consistent fashion.
15.11.2014. Ruby colour. Aroma of ripe fruits, berries. Tastes berries, fruits, hoppy bitterness.

Very deep copper, almost opaque. Deep copper, loose off-white head. Flavours of toast, caramel, cereal, slightly earthy, plenty of malt. Mild to moderate bitterness. Medium bodied, light carbonation. Brilliant.

From a cask at the O'Connell's, Tampere, Finland. 
Dark reddish brown colour with a foamy light tan head. 
A mild chocolatey malty aroma. 
The flavour is roasted malt, coffee, bitterness, hops and newspaper. Wow! Far from fresh. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cask @ OConnels Freehouse.
Pours dark ruby red color with a medium sized head. Creamy, some chocolate and caramel on the nose. Flavor doesnt differ much, nutty and chocolaty with mild berry notes. Decent.
3414
191214. Cask at OConnells, Tampere. Pours clear dark ruby with a head(!). Aroma toffee, caramel, fruit, malts. Slightly sweet palate. Smooth after taste. Very nice. Not Bad.

Draft at 'The Flag', Watford. 
Pours a very dark ruby with a firm light beige head. Malty taste with a little licquorice. Excellent!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On cask at the Haymarket. 
Appearance - opaque black but with some red to orange chinks. 
Nose - gentle liquorice and charcoal. Malt dryness. 
Taste - more liquorice and some small hint of black cherry. 
Palate - medium bodied with a dry texture and a long dry finish. 
Overall - great mild with a nod to the porter or dry stout style.

Cask at Shakespeare Bham ; dark mahogany red pour with a frothy beige head, nut and dark fruit aroma, taste has light coffee, dark fruits, excellent mouthfeel, awesome example of how cask can knock you off you feet at anytime.
Cask @ York brewery. Fine bubbles foam. One finger. Malty dark brown. Some sweet-bitterness. Gentle. Medium body. Nice after a lot of ordinary ale's...
Cask in Turners Mill, Redcar. Pours ruby with a tight off-white head. Good rich fruity flavour with chocolate notes. Some coffee in the bitter finish. A good traditional beer.
Cask at Three Legged Mare, York. Pours red-brown, thin off-white head. Aromas of chocolate and light roast. Taste has more, and light sweetness. Enjoyed this.
Cask the tap room batley. Dark ruby beer good beige head and lacing. Aroma is roasted malts fruits. Taste is similar nice bitter finish. Medium body soft carbonated. Decent stuff.
Dark amber, aroma is nutty and caramelly, mellow sweet malts. Decent stiff but the alcohol comes in late.

Cask at Angleterre. Dark brown color, white head. Bittersweet taste wit roasted malts, nuts, citrus, vegetables, spices and grass. Bitter finish with citrus, vegetables and roasted malts. Pretty unpleasant experience.

(Cask at Angleterre, 20131229) The beer poured dark brown and clear. Its head was small, long lasting, dense and almost white. Aroma had malts, molasses and English hops. Palate was medium bodied with low carbonation. Flavours were malts, caramel, sweet English hops, earth and bitterness. Aftertaste was malty, grassy and bitter. A nice malty English style brew.

Pint on Cask from Three Legged Mare, York, England (£2.50):
Dark chocolate and some sugar hits you upfront, with some mild hops and a few earthy malts as well. There is a few fruits lingering as well as a creamy, roasted malt aroma.

Dark ruby to black with a quarter centimetre tall head that is a creamy white and holds quite well, leaving lots of lacing on the glass too.

Dark malts and some stronger cocoa make an appearance along with a sweet, almost creamy taste of chocolate and some coffee. There is the roasted malts from the nose as well, plus a nutty flavour and some barely and fruits towards the end.

Soft carbonation on top of a medium to full body and mild bitterness with a generally smooth feel on the mouth and some faint sweetness.

Dark and quite sweet with a great body and quite a rich, flavoursome taste that is very easy to drink and quite enjoyable. One of the better cask beers Ive had and another I wouldnt might trying a bottle of in future.
Cask by gravity at Paisley Beer Festival - clear dark brown with a reddish tint, non-existent head, sour malty aroma, coffee, dark chocolate, sour malty aftertaste
Cask at Last Drop Inn, York. Dark ruby body with brown head. Sweet, malty, a bit of a roasted finish. Quite nice.

Cask at the Yorkshire Terrier. Pours darkly ruddy orange with a tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, slight roast malt. Full bodied or nearly. Flavor is lighter dark fruit with maybe a hint of chocolate. Or not. Finishes slightly on the sweet side with enough hop to keep it tasty. Nice.

Draught @ The Last Drop Inn, York. Scotland trip. Dark brown almost black coloured beerwith a small dence creamy off white heaD. Light roasted malty with a short bitter hinted aroma. Medium to full creamy palate. Finish is malty bitter, light malty roasted with a longer bitter creamy ending. Not bad.
Half pint at the UK National Winter Ales Festival 2013.  Black, with little head.  Nice light chocolate aroma.  Very pleasant session beer, smooth, although its a touch watery.
Half pint. Pours a dark red with a thick creamy head. Aroma is choppy and of molasses. Great taste, just right. Slightly bigger with coffee and hops both present. Very nice.
A deep ruby beer with a nice thick head, that invites to have another one. On a rainy day with a pie.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Stoops Chesterfield. Dark ruby with wonderful long lasting head and a coffee,fruity taste to die for.  For this type of beer you would be hard pressed to find one much better. At  5.4 it can hardly be described as a session beer,but that,s exactly what it is. You could drink this stuff all night and still want more. The landlord says it will be returning soon. Tomorrow wouldn,t be soon enough. Well looked after and a joy to drink.
A pleasant mild with a roasted aroma.  Black and headless with an understated taste.
Great beer, nice thick creamy head which develops over a minute or two as the punt settles , lovley flavour slight malts and roast, chocolates, hazelnut one of my favourites on draft

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2012 Perhaps my favourite Yorkshire beer. Have not had yet in August, but I have imbibed this beauty enough to know it by heart. 
On cask whenever I can. Ruby red with a nice thick head. Akin to having liquified fruits and nuts. A champion beer of Britain with good reason!
An excellent full bodied dark beer with a pleasant chocolate undertaste. One of the best.
Clear with a deep red-brown color with creamy tan head.  Chocolate and roasty in aroma.  Chocolatey malty body, with hop bitterness to balance to the dry side but little hop flavor.

(draught) pours a darkest ruby-brown colour with a frothy beige head. aroma of toasted malts and raisins, with a hint of milk chocolate. flavour is more on the sweet side, lots of liquorice and raisins, with a hint of toasted malts and a medium roasted-bitter finish. light to medium-bodied with soft carbonation.

On tap at wetherspoons, doncaster.
Create off white head.  Deep ruby pour.  Lovely smooth aftertaste. Yummy!

On cask at the Three Legged Mare. Pours a dark brown colour with a red glow and a fair light tan head. Aroma of caramel, chocolate, yeast and alcohol. Similar flavours with mild carbonation and an oily mouth-feel. Mildly bitter with a dry finish. Alcohol is fairly present with lingering chocolate and plums.

Dark brown with a red tint. Thin dissapearing tan lacy head. Smells of light roast chocolate malt, fruit and sweet malt. Thin light medium body. Nice sweetness cherry, and a lasting bitter chocolate roast finish. Doesnt feel like an Old Ale, more like a strong Mild. Very much enjoyed this one.

First had this beer at the Paisley Beer Festival in April 2000. It was a ruby red colour back then with a malty marmalade flavour - nothing special I noted. Went to York in 2005 and tried it again. What a difference? A change for the better!! Dark ruby in colour with a thick tight creamy head. Good dense mouthfeel and silky smooth texture. Complex roast malts combined with dry black malt gave this strong bitter a well balanced taste. Raisin fruit and juicy sultana notes combine well with a smokey oak flavour. Dry hop bitterness detected in the aftertaste. Finish is malty with woodsmoke dryness and a touch of liquorice in the mouth. Highly drinkable and well recommended.

Cask. Deep brown with a tan head. The nose is of roasted malts, chocolate, some dark grains. The taste is moderately bittersweet. Some cherries and bitter chocolate. Light bitter finish. From notes: "full-bodied, just like your mum". So apparently I was quite happy with this pint.

Cask @ York Brewery pub. An almost black colored beer, with a thick beige head. The aroma of some coffee with nuts and malt. The taste is some sweet, dry, coffee notes, and gentle bitter. The aftertaste is a little sweet moving to bitter.

Cask in The Dog & Duck. Colour is ruby brown bitter. Nose is milk chocolate, roasted malt, fruity hops, malty. Taste is caramel, milk chocolate, roasted malt and a fruity kick. Not too bitter and nice chocolatey very malty finish.
Very impressive ale. For a 5.4% ale it was very easy to drink, malty, dark bitter, does exactly what is says on the tin, nutty, coffee, lovely. Darker beers fast becoming my favourites.
user_location: Chapel en le Frith, Derbyshire, ENGLAND

text: On cask at White Star, Stoke on Trent.  Ive been lucky with beers today.  A dark beer with a white head.  Nutty, coffee, well balanced.  Excellent

Cask handpull, The Yorkshire Terrier, York, 17/04/11. Deep ruby with copper tints and a fine tan collar. Ash, leaves, dark fruits wreathed with choc aroma. Deep and tempting with a soft plethora of malt flavours; Tia Maria, damp leaves, hint of orange cream (Roses). Good chocolate and ashy linger. Rich, complex beer that even survives the sparkler treatment. Suck of barrel, big syrupy body. Decent beer in York at last.

Cask at NWAF, 2011. Brown pour with a beige head. Aromas of vanilla, caramel, milk chocolate. Quite  a sweet nose. Toffee, caramel flavours, also a strong fruit presence. Malty, fruity finish. Interesting.
16th November 2007  Warning! Early amateur rating! Spoons Winter Fest. A dark and drinkable ale with hints of fruit, chocolate and malt. Bitter malt. Good stuff.

Cask at the Doric Arch, Euston, London on 13 October 2010. Deep red with thin white ring of foam. Christmas berries and dark chocolate. Spice and berry fruits in-mouth. Smooth cooling texture and a spicy, fruity finish.

Cask at Argyll Arms, London. Pours cloudy, dark brown with a small, off-white head. Dark malt aroma with light fruit and nuts. Fairly sweet, with a strong coffee note hitting first. Also hints of caramel, chocolate and brown sugar. Light to medium in body with soft carbonation. The finish is nicely sweet, with bits of burnt sugar and roasted coffee beans, along with mild, dry bitterness. Great beer.

Cask: Dark amber coloured, creamy off-white lacy head; delicate dry roasty and fruity (brambles) nose; dry moderate to solid bitter-sweet flavour, medium bodied, quite soft; dry lingering bitter-roasty and fruity finish. Just good.....

cask at Bow Bar - Pours dark brown with a light tan head.  The aroma is mainly roast caramel malt.  It tastes of sweet, roasted malt with a bit of caramel and a touch of dark fruit.  Its fairly good but its a little bland.

Cask - The Bell Hotel (JDW), Norwich. Dark brown in colour with a medium, lasting creamy beige head. Initial buttery aromas and flavours that gradually settle to allow some dark fruit to come through on the nose. On the palate, the diacetyl gives way to bitter roasted malts and chocolate with a drop of dark fruit at the back. A lingering bitterness, soft palate and medium body. A bit rich for the summer heat but pretty darn good as soon as the diacetyl gave out.
UPDATED: JAN 29, 2012 Cask. The Yorkshire Terrier, York. 4 8 7 4 14. Medium off white head. Deep mahogany body. Toffee, caramel, fruit, spicy. Bittersweet. Warming. Sweet finish,

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2010 Cask @ Ayrshire Real Ale Festival 09. Black colour, tan head. Aroma of sweet malts and fruits. Flavour of toasted malts and fruits. Slightly bitter. Not much going on.

Rerate. Cask @ Society Room, JDW. Bit of roasted malts, watery.
Cask at Reading beerfest. Copper coloured ale. Fruity, malty and roasty. A very well balanced beer from York. I could happily drink this all evening as a session beer, top draw this one.

Tap at maproom.  A nice reddish brown pour with a big bubbled head.  Lots of caramel malt, woody notes and very ight dusting of hops.  Flavor is fairly benign.  Malty, caramle, cookie and some quite faint hop flavors.  Not bad.

-mperial pint on draft shared with Daknole and his brother in law. Pours a rich dark brown with tannish head that clings to the edges. Aromas throw off light caramel and biscuit sweetness with just a faint touch of florals. Taste is light on body, packing some caramel and biscuit with light bitterness. Touch of chocolate, very light carbonation. Finish with a touch of sweetness. A little underwhelming, but nice.
Cask, Crescent, Salford. Red tinged dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma of furniture polish, burnt wood and malt. Sweetish flavour had dark fruit, nuts and caramel malt. Pretty tasty stuff.

Cask at Bricklayers Arms Yorskhire Festival, 27th February 2009. Dark ruby brown with a foamy head. Rich chocolate and fruit flavour. Nice and tasty. Almost perfumy at the finish and drys the tongue well. A good quality dark beer.
cask Bricklayers beer fest putney.Dark ale with fat maltines tang.The caramel thing you always gets in ESB.sOME PLUM ?I reckon.

2008-11-11, Cask Conditioned at J. D. Wetherspoon - The Knights Templar, London, 6-4-6-3-12=31Dark brown color, almost black, with red shades; thin frothy head. Very light caramel and chocolate aroma. There is some caramel and chocolate flavor, malt, residual sweetness and a refreshing touch, without the aggressivity of the last time I tried it; correct bitterness. It won the Brewing Industries International Award Gold Medal, but Im not impressed, pleasant anyway.2008-10-20, Cask Conditioned at Doric Arch, London, 5-3-6-2-11= 27Very dark brown color. Aroma of roasted malt, ashes. Medium body, with clearly a roasted malt flavor, getting stronger (and more bitter) at the end; dry mouthfeel of aggressive coffee. A fair beer, but I dont fancy so much this bitter coffee flavor.

[Cask at Back of Beyond, Reading] Deep reddish-brown with a foamy off-white head.  Smells and tastes like a stout with lots of toasty malt flavours evident.  Initially very enjoyable, but by the end the bitterness had grown to a level where it was detracting from my enjoyment of the beer.  Not a bad effort all the same.
Handpulled cask at JDW Hatch End, Harrow. Ruby brown with an off-white head. Full flavour of roasted malts and toffee. Good earthy hoppy finish. Very good.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2008 Cask-conditioned at the Commercial Rooms JDW, Bristol. Mahogany coloured with a decent beige head. Big fruit, roasted malt and toffee aroma. Flavour was sweet, with plenty of caramel, dried fruit, chocolate and earthy hops, before a long bitter finish. Very good.

From cask at Standing Order. Pours dark brown to black with a creamy off-white head. Light metallic and roasted malt aroma. Flavour is hardroasted and towards slight acidic with a distinct yet light acidic to metallic note. Smooth malty finish.

Deep brown-ruby tinted beer with a thin off-white head.  Aroma is quite sweet and malty with a prominent dried date/date honey character along with some molasses and dried fruitiness on the back end.  Dried plums.  Warming really intensifies the sweet character and brings out a touch of licorice as well.  Quite sweet but it works very well.

Cask, gravity dispense at Merton Summer Beer Festival July 18th and 19th 2008 (had this on the Saturday morning when all was quite and after icing up , this was quite nice for breakfast at 07:30)   Pours mid brown with some woodiness hazlenut and roasted flavours and aromas floating around. The maltiness starts to make its mark and there is a tangy enduring bitterness, its a fine beers but not quite the beer I anticipated.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2008 Dark brown/black half pint at local beer festival.  Pours with no head and looks a bit like flat cola!

Taste is strong hops and yeast, a little sweetness and caramel followed by a pleasant bitter after taste.

Very enjoyable.

Cask RA. Dark brown colour. A quite tasty beer. Suitable sweetness. Some
hoppiness in the end. Also some prunes and roasted toffee in the taste.

Cask at the Last Drop Inn, York. This dark beer was very enjoyable on a very chilly night. Its dark brown with lost of roast malt on the nose and in the flavour but with some fruit and chocolate qualities. Quite good.

Cask @ York Brewery, november 07. Clear, deep dark copper color with a medium, light tan head. Deep fruity flavor with some very slight earthy hop notes. Ends with a dried fruits touch. Deep, profound, rasiny fruity aroma. Medium to full palate, caramel feeling but ends quite dry and earthy. Excellent strong english ale.
Cask handpump at The White Horse, Harborne, Birmingham. Black with a good-sized foam head. Strong coffee scent. Some sweetness. Coffee and liquorice in the mouth. Dry end. Not too rich.
cask Aberdeen Beer festival 07 ... Deep brown ... musty hop ... roast slight burntness... with a tinge of sourness... just want working ofr me.

Counting house for wetherspoons beer fest. Aroma is quite floural with hints of citrus hops, rich spicey juicey malt backing. Taste is juicey peppery malts up fronjt with a good amount of grassy and cirtic hops to make it super drinkable.

Cask, Quorn Fest 07.  Very dark brown with a beige foam.  Aromas are floral with soap, melon and pear.  Dark malts that are quite sweet.  Flavours are dark chocolate with some vinous berries.  Fruity and quite rich.  Light dry finish.

Gravity, Oxford CAMRA beer festival.  Simple brown, light tan head. Deep leathery caramel aroma (the sort of smell that touches some buried kid-in-candystore sort of ecstasy), soft chocolate, coffee roast backbone and a bit of toasty biscuit. Lovely deep caramel and rum sweetness given texture and depth by a lovely roasty edge. Soft, full, inviting. Seriously impressive beer, and my beer of the festival.

Almost a black beer with a slightly malty and slightly coffee aroma.  The flavour is slightly coffee and malty.  Overall a nice roasted coffee beer.

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense

Comments: I was not particularly enthusiast about this one when getting a small sample, but I had a half-pint at the 3-legged-mare in York and it was in awesome condition. I think it may have been my favourite cask ale ever, or close. Marvellously crisp, dense, almost chewy dark malts bursting with delicious toastiness. Bright hop bitterness, stupendous balance.

Cask (handpump) @ GBBF 2007, London. Clear medium to dark brown color with a small to average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, fruity, moderate english licorice. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat.

(Cask at GBBF, London, 8 Aug 2007) Dark brown colour with ruby notes, brief beige head. Malty, roasted nose with notes of dark fruit, blackberries and coffee. Malty, roasted taste with coffee, dark bitter chocolate, chicory, ripe fruit and coffee bitter notes of hops in a long finish. Delicious, hearty and warming.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Dark amber colour, mediumsized brownish head. Aroma is caramel, wood, some fruits and a bit of grass. Flavour is wooden and grassy with mild notes of caramel.

Cask (Gallows Bird, Espoo, Real Ale Festival 2007).
Sharp bitterness wrapped in a sticky chocolatey coating. Very well balanced and full flavoured.
Cask @ Real Ale Festival, Gallows Bird, Espoo. Dark brown colour with a small white head. Taste very oaky. Nice nutty aroma, even a bit chocolaty.

A Mes rate: Cask at Baker St. JDW. Mmm this was a bit of a treat. Roasted chocolate malt and lots of dark fruits. Balances out pretty well for the finish. Good body, good dark ruby colour. A malty treat all round.

Very dark tan coloured. Thin off-white head. Roasted, almost smoky to the nose. Dark fruits, spices (pepper) and dark chocolate can be detected in a complex flavour. Medium to full bodied. Slightly bitter aftertaste. Tasty! (Half pint on gravity at The St Albans Beer Festival 28.09.2006).

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2006 1.cask at last drop inn, york:  darker that typical bitter.  dark brown with normal white cask head.  nice roasted notes throughout the drink with some fruitiness mixed in.  Increasingly bitter towards the finish.  Well balanced.  medium heavy palate.  solid brew 2. gets bumbed up a couple of notches on the rerate.  very porter like in aroma and flavor.  very rich and roasty with some hop presents.  quite tasted and has a good mouthfeel.  I really dont think its a bitter though.
Cask @ GBBF 2006. Dark amber colour with a small off-white head.  Malted roasted and fruity aroma with some hints of chocolate. Sweet malty hoppy bitter flavor. Dry malty and fruity finish.

Handpump @ the Last Drop Inn, York, Nth Yorkshire. 
Deep ruby red, still and sparkling in the lights topped off with a thin, tannish pad of cream that retained well and had a similar high sheen sparkle. Woody aged fruit nose, tangy but dry with a light peppery spice. Quite pleasant. Smoky and rich burnt fruits in the mouth. Quite full and creamy with a light hint of cherry sweetness upfront before drying out and showing an array of spicy, aged fruits, dark chocolate, peat and woody malts with a touch of roasted coffee beans. Burnt wood and bitter malts finish it off smoothly and the length the flavour lasts on the palate is divine. I really took a shine to this one. Its not too intense, but it borderlined on session beer and one for quiet contemplation. A lovely, balanced, malt driven ale.

Had this at the brewery in York.  Dark mahogony body with a light tan head.  Raisin, apple, cherry and pine in the aroma.  Chocolate hops and malt dominate the taste, some light coffee.  Nice bitter ending that has more character than most English ales Ive had in England.

Cask conditioned - handpump - The Last Drop York. Almost deep dark brown body, tan coloured head. Dark fruit taste which was lovely, better than the porter which I quite liked (maybe I have had enough ) just a bit easier to drink, prunes but good.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2006 Cask gravity at Catford BF 06. Deep ruby with lasting beige head. Choccy aroma, bit flat, smooth, powdery hoc. Fairly good. Bit too powdery. 3.4/5

Re-rate Cask gravity at The George, Bethersden.  
Deep dark brown/ruby with tan head. Dark malt aroma, choc, but also hop too. Nicely full in mouth. Nicely roasted malt. Doesnt drink its strength. Good dark strong beer.
Very dark reddish brown with a small beige head. Complex aroma of pear and malt. Warm, roasted taste with porterish hints of musty, smoky malt. Late, lingering bitterness. Good beer.
Cask at Last Drop Inn York 3 May 06. Dark brown - almost black. A burned aroma. Long coffee-filled aftertaste. More like a stout than a bitter. Enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2010 1. Cask Stillage at the Swan Inn, Stone 20/07/2001
Ruby coloured and fruity. Woody flavoured finish.
2. Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich (JDW) 15/10/2004
Mid to dark brown coloured with a very fruity flavour. Slightly dry lasting malt finish.
3. Cask Handpump at the Golden Fleece, York 20/02/2008
Fruity slightly pale and rich aromas. Creamy head. Dark coloured strong in alcohol fruity and pale with some bitterness in a warming roast finish.
4. Cask Handpump at the Waterhouse JDW, Manchester 25/04/2010
Fruit and some roast aromas. Creamy head. Dark red coloured strong in alcohol and fruity with a little dryness in a bitter coffee roast finish.

Cask (handpulled) at the Lincolnshire Poacher, Nottingham.  The best beer on a great day in this ever-improvign beer city. Stout-ish looks, deep dark body and creamy head. Chocolate and roasty bits waft off, well roasted flavour, a simple finish.

Cask conditioned GBBF 2005:
Bean aroma. Quite malty and sligtly bitter. Somewhat roasted and slightly burnt. A nice beer.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2006 Handpump @ The Porcupine, Charing Cross Rd, London, UK. I hope Im writing on this beer, it just read ghost on the pump (the barman said it was a special halloween beer), but the %alc. and the colour match the data given here...? Very dark red, solid head. Aroma: fruity, liqueur, sharp hops. The taste begins quietly, continues estery (melon, pepper), finishes very hop bitter. Strong body.
UPDATED: FEB 8, 2006 Really good one, smoked, like coffe, and the foam was like in a stout. But it was too strong and I guess my stomach don/t want much beer by the moment.

Dark red/brown colour. Mainly dry malt in the aroma. Bits of dark chocolate and roasty malt in the flavour. Dry finish with some bitterness. It is certainly easy to drink, as the blurb suggests, but the downside of that is that its not packed with flavour for a relatively strong ale. But the balance is good and its a likeable beer. Cask (gravity dispense), White Cliffs Beer Festival, February 2005.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2010 Feb, 2008 Dover Fest. Soft creamy dark and malty ale with interesting twiggy bits among the dark caramel. Pleasantly enjoyable. [3.9]
June, 2010 JDW, Rochester. Dark and roasty with a pleasant jammy sweetness. Very nice. Very nice indeed. [3.9]

On hand pump from the Cask in The Ale, Derby. No Sparkler as it was "football night".

(Despite the ABV on this page the Yorks Centurions Ghost I had was 5.4%)

A dark red-ish brown in colour, this was a strong malty beer with a distinct Roasted Malt note to it.

The taste of alcohol is a bit to strong to be very drinkable though
CAsk conditioned. Quite dark. Some caramel and roast malt in the palate. Bitter but not overly so. Some tartness. On the whole not bad at all.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2010 Cask conditioned - handpump - Three Legged Mare York.  A ruby red beer with a thick creamy head due to the tight sparkled dispense.  A malty clean tasting beer but way too thin.  I have drank this before from the same pub and really enjoyed it, so very disappointed this time around.  Score 2.7Subsequent rating scored 3.3. Average becomes 3.0

Clear dark redbrown color, thick creamy lasting "Guinness" head. Aroma of whisky, coffee, milk chocolate, only some roasted malts. Tast is very creamy, deep roasted and chocolate malts. Sticky palate.

Cask-conditioned @ Railway Arms, Alton. Deep ruby colour. Malty, bready, caramel and toasty aromas. Reasonably dry with some roasty bitterness. A touch thin and doesnt quite come together in the finish.

Hand pulled at the Anchor, Birmingham. I must have been having an off night, because I thought this was a Porter or possibly an Old Ale - it seemed very dark and had strong roasted coffee/flavours. Fairly watery consistency, picking up to an interesting finish. A flat espresso taste, medium dry. Pleasant, but not outstanding.

Bright bottled, from the Thurrock Beer Festival.  Dark brown, with frothy brown head. Roasted malt flavour and a bitterness that sneaks up on you. Strong bitter backbone and long lasting palate kind of make me think this could be an ESB. Pretty dam nice.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2004 (Cask Conditioned at the Three Legged Mare, York, England)  This dak bitter ale pours with a medium, tan head.  The ale has a descent blend of sweetness and roasted chocolate under tones.

[Cask at Stockholm Beer Festival 2003] The nose is light with some roasted and chocolate notes. The color dark red and it has a light-brown head. The taste is great - a complex maltblend with a good sweetness combined with roasted and chocolate malt. It ends on a nice bitterness from the malts used.

Cask Conditioned at Last Drop Inn, York.
Dark to deep Red in colour, thin head. This is the big one of the York range for me. I wouldn't describe it as a bitter, its more an Old Ale, or strong Mild. Big sweet fruity flavour almost a little flabby. Mushy blackberries come to mind but with an underlying spicyness. Drank several and every one was good. I now have a bottle but I see it isn't B.C so maybe the quality will not show through in that.

Sampled cask conditioned at Oliver Twist, Stockholm, Sweden.
Dark brownish ruby. Neutral nose. Malty, sweet and near full bodied. Really chewy and lightly fruity with soft mouthfeel and a short lightly grassy finish with low bitterness. Overall this is a very rounded malty ale with a low hoprate.
UPDATED: DEC 24, 2003 Cask conditioned. Deep red brown, moderate creamy white head. Chocolatey malt aroma that carries through into the thick creamy body before a slightly syrupy malt finish.
